Reason #21 why you should vote: your vote matters.

Reason #20 why you should vote: workers shouldn’t have to choose between earning a paycheck and spending time with their newborn or taking care of a sick family member. It’s time for paid family and sick leave policies.
Reason #19 why you should vote: so immigrants aren’t forced into the shadows. We are a stronger nation because of our diversity.

Reason #18 why you should vote: to elect a Congress that will pass legislation to protect Dreamers. They are Americans in every way except on paper. It’s time we honor our promise to them and give them a permanent solution so they can live up to their full potential.
Reason #17 why you should vote: so violence against women and children is taken more seriously everywhere — from the courts to Congress.
Reason #16 why you should vote: to elect leaders on November 6 who will address the affordable housing crisis.
Reason #15 why you should vote: to raise the federal minimum wage. With costs of living skyrocketing, you can’t live off of $7.25 an hour. It’s time to raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour.
Reason #14 why you should vote: LGBTQ rights. No one should be denied work, service, a place to live, or the opportunity to serve their country because of who they are or who they love.
Reason #13 why you should vote: campaign finance reform. Special interests and large corporations have spent millions to buy elections. It’s time to get big money out of politics.
Reason #12 why you should vote: to elect politicians who will help provide teachers with the tools and resources they need to do their job — educating our students.
Reason #11 why you should vote: to strengthen Social Security and Medicare. Every American deserves the ability to retire with dignity.
Reason #10 why you should vote: so our nation’s daughters grow up knowing their work is worth just as much as our sons. We need to make equal pay for equal work a reality.
Reason #9 why you should vote: for criminal justice reform. One of the first steps to reforming our broken criminal justice system is by replacing our bail system.
Reason #8 why you should vote: to keep families together.
Reason #7 why you should vote: to ensure that everyone has the ability to breathe clean air and live in a safe and healthy environment.
Reason #6 why you should vote: to decriminalize marijuana at the federal level. Too many lives have been ruined because of our regressive policies.
Reason #5 why you should vote: to protect Roe v. Wade.
Reason #4 why you should vote: so we can create a future where everyone in America can go to college without being weighed down by mountains of debt.
Reason #3 why you should vote: Medicare for All. Quality, affordable health care should be a right for all Americans, not a privilege for the few.
Reason #2 why you should vote: to elect leaders who will work to protect our children from gun violence in schools.
With 21 days to go until Election Day, here are 21 reasons why you should vote for Democrats. Reason #1: to create a better and brighter future for the next generation.

From her, I learned to ask questions, gather evidence, and test hypotheses. I learned that no idea is too precious to be rigorously examined. I learned how to fight for justice and live a life of conscience, and I think of her every day.
My mother became a pioneering breast cancer researcher. She maintained her lab at Lawrence Berkeley until the day she died; she knew that the search for truth was a lifelong effort.

She and my father met while they were active in the civil rights movement. My sister Maya and I actually joke that we grew up surrounded by a bunch of adults marching and shouting for this thing called justice. We were raised on stories of the upheaval and activism of the 1960s.
There’s a photo I cherish of her and one of her best friends in life, my Auntie Lenore, standing in front of a sign that says, “Protest Birmingham atrocities. Write the president.”

Like many of you, I’m spending today thinking about my mother. She was all of 5 feet, but she could move mountains, as she proved when she crossed an ocean at age 19 to study here.pic.twitter.com/NtPAEpeQs1
